I see so many founders making this same mistake with social selling.
They assume people will read their content.

When what they should be doing is giving people a reason to read it by leading with value.

Social media is the most competitive space there is:
- Global
- Limited attention
- Few barriers to entry

So why should someone read your post about your business? They’ve seen 6 like it today.

Now I’m not saying don’t post about your business.

But you need to give value first.

Why?
- Leverages reciprocity bias
- Positions you as an expert
- Builds trust

One of the best ways to do this is with a lead magnet.

A once of resource that you can redistribute without any extra effort. For example: a PDF guide on the best growth tools for startups.

A once of resource that you can redistribute without any extra effort. For example: a PDF guide on the best growth tools for startups.

And make sure it has an unbelievable amount of value.

You want to leave people wowed.

Here are two great examples:
- Greg Isenberg (30 business ideas)
- Chenell Basilio (Creator growth tactics database)

This is where a lot of founders stop.

But it’s where the magic starts.

Email is an inherently personal channel. You’re around friends, family, and work.

So as long as you continue to give practical value to your readers. The more personal you feel to them.

Meaning:
- More trust
- More engagement
- More sales

To bring it back an example above, Greg does a great job of giving his readers value in his newsletter.

Week after week.

Now when anyone who reads it needs design help, SEO work, or is looking to sell some of their business. Guess where they go?

Trivago.

I mean Greg of course.

One-time value is often not enough.

You need to create a system that constantly nurtures leads.

If you want to chat about how you can build a value-led, lead-nurturing machine, send me a DM and we can jump on a call!

Want a free way to cut churn and boost revenue?

Create a group chat with your top users.

Simple. But the impact? Massive.

Pick a platform your users already use:
- Slack
- Discord
- WhatsApp
- (Maybe skip the post office)

Creators make millions. Yet can’t get credit.
I studied how Karat raised $100M to build a bank for creators. Here’s what I learned:

To put this into scale. Karat Financial  serves Creators with over 1 billion total followers. That's the same as:
- 4 MrBeasts
- 60 KSIs, or
- 715 Colin and Samirs

Here's how they did it:

1️⃣ Build for an underserved market

Traditional banks don't get creators.

They're stuck in the past. Using outdated credit scores that don't capture a creator's true financial power. Leading to some crazy situations:

- Nas Daily: Global creator, Harvard Econ grad, ex-Venmo dev. Making $3M+.

Leading to some crazy situations:

- Nas Daily: Global creator, Harvard Econ grad, ex-Venmo dev. Making $3M+. Rejected for a business credit card.

- Alexandra Botez: Chess Twitch star, Stanford grad, ex-YC founder. 875k followers, ~$50-70k/month. Rejected twice.

Karat's solution? A unique underwriting model based on:
- Creator income
- Income sources (e.g., stable Twitch subs vs. volatile TikTok ads)
-Social stats (followers, growth, engagement)

Result: Higher limits and better rates for creators.

2️⃣ Solve a problem a subset of users care deeply about

Creators need capital for three main reasons:
1. Working capital: Speeds up video production
2.

Working capital: Speeds up video production
2. Business investment: Think Dude Perfect building a theme park
3. Personal credit: Home loans, etc.

Only reason #1 is truly urgent.

But it only affects a small group of creators who have high video costs.

Key lesson: It's better to solve a burning problem for a few than a mild inconvenience for many.

Karat's strategy:
1. Target top creators with urgent working capital needs
2. Watch others follow suit

So ask yourself -> is your product solving a problem people lose sleep over?

3️⃣ Leverage connectors

If you have a great product. Connectors are the ones who will make it viral.

So prioritise acquiring and serving them.

Karat's secret weapon? Creators - the ultimate connectors.

So prioritise acquiring and serving them.

Karat's secret weapon? Creators - the ultimate connectors.

But you don't need creators. You need trusted voices in your industry:
- Look on LinkedIn for thought leaders
- Network at industry events
- Identify the faces everyone knows

These are your potential brand ambassadors and inherent distribution channels.

Eric Wei Will Kim

I spent the last two weeks studying how Arc scaled to a $550M valuation. Here’s how Arc grew by bringing the joy back to product:

1️⃣ Creating moments of joy:

The best part about Arc is its little moments of joy.

Be it:
- Little animations
- Sound effects
- Or the ability to create your own theme.

You’re eagerly waiting for the next surprise.

Importantly, these are different for aha moments.

Where the core value of your product clicks with a user, they get it, and they activate.

These are moments sprinkled on top.

That you know you don’t need.

But which make using the product fun and delightful.

Increasing the chance of you spreading the word of Arc.

The great thing about these moments of joy?

They stack on top of each other and snowball.

The great thing about these moments of joy?

They stack on top of each other and snowball.

Individually you enjoy each one.

But together you fall in love with the product.

2️⃣ Optimize for feelings:

Arc challenged what they were really optimizing for.

The browser is one of the most used products in a person’s day.

It’s important to keep the product human-focused.

Arc views this as optimizing for feelings over data.

Believing that data often leads to optimizing for the wrong things.

Instead Arc put the craft of the product at the forefront.

With data as a secondary source.

Arc does not only serve your functional needs.

But also your emotional ones.

Arc is trying to bring humanity back to software.

Not at the expense of data.

But rather using feelings to guide the nuances missed by data.

Arc is trying to bring humanity back to software.

Not at the expense of data.

But rather using feelings to guide the nuances missed by data.

Using data as the what and feelings as the why.

3️⃣ Redefining interaction on the user journey - aka the membership team:

The world of tech has in many ways unified the way to build teams.

You have product, design, user research, customer success, customer support, engineering, etc. etc.

But what if it didn’t have to be like that?

That’s exactly what Arc asked when building out their team.

So rather than create teams with predefined notions of what to do.

They created new ones:

Specifically their Membership and Storytelling Teams.

But what does this have to do with UX?

Well, everything really.

They created new ones:

Specifically their Membership and Storytelling Teams.

But what does this have to do with UX?

Well, everything really.

Because that’s the way the Membership team is designed.

Traditionally, there are different teams for different touch points in a user’s journey.

But not at Arc.

They view the relationship with their members as holistic.

The same team that takes you from your first touchpoint

To your (hopefully never quite) last.

This continuous relationship with their members builds them extreme loyalty and brand advocacy.

The Browser Company Josh Miller Hursh Agrawal

Most founders make this same mistake:

Growing is not just about your own posts.

You need to engage with other people’s content.

To get noticed by them and their audience.

To get noticed by them and their audience.

🎬 𝐀𝐜𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧𝐬:

- Comment meaningful replies to their posts on a daily basis.

The above steps drive people to your content.

Now you need to have content to show them.

And I promise you, in just 5-10 minutes you can create a well-written, valuable post (I didn’t used to believe this).

On those other 3 days focus on relationships.

The best creators all have this in common:

(and it starts before they publish anything)

They know their Market of One.

The one person they create most of their content for.

I spent 25+ hours studying how Stan scaled to $30M helping creators make a living online. Here’s what I learned:

1️⃣ Customer > everything:

Building a great product is not about adding features you think will be cool.

It’s about deeply understanding and empathizing with your customers.

And using that to shape your product.

But how did Stan do this practically?

By trying to find out who would be extremely disappointed if they could not use Stan again. And why.

They then went a level deeper.

Why would that reason leave them extremely disappointed?

And they kept asking “why” until they got to the core of what their customers loved the most.

That Stan helped them make money.

And they kept asking “why” until they got to the core of what their customers loved the most.

That Stan helped them make money.

Specifically:
- How simple it was to get set up (It only takes a creator an average of 10 minutes to create a store)
- How easy the checkout process was for their customers

Stan then doubled down on these.

Introducing new features that helped creators make money, like email marketing, as well as adding features that made checkout even more seamless.

Not stopping here, Stan went deeper on why their casual fans were not fanatics and addressed their issues.

Eg. Making Stan look nicer.

The Stan team kept doing this until they eventually reached 45% (a massive jump from the original 10%) of customers saying they would be extremely disappointed if they couldn’t use Stan again.

Great products lead to success for customers →
Which leads to customers referring Stan →
Which leads to new customers →
Which leads to them having success →
Which leads to them referring Stan…
And the flywheel continues.

The average Stan customer now refers over 2 new users over their lifetime.

Remember, you’re building a product for your customers.

Don’t guess what they want. Speak to them.

2️⃣ Building in public:

Founder John Hu produces some of the best business YouTube videos.

Delivering value-packed, authentic, entertaining, and inspirational content.

John comes across as a likable guy with a great idea.

And after one video, I wanted to see him win.

As I imagine many others did.

But not only is he using content to build a community behind him.

As I imagine many others did.

But not only is he using content to build a community behind him.

He is reaching his customers where they hang out.

On YouTube and TikTok.

With every video Stan and John build more trust.
- Showing Stan’s financials
- Critiquing his mistakes
- Opening up about struggles with mental health

3️⃣ Building an All-Star team:

To build a successful company you need great people.

How you are judged as a founder, ultimately, is how well you hire.

As Graham Weaver, founder of Alpine Investors put it in his interview with John:

If you hire B grade people:
You are a B grade leader.

If you want to be an A+ leader:
You need to hire A+ people.

This is something Stan has done really well.

They never rushed hiring.

This is something Stan has done really well.

They never rushed hiring.

Only filling a role when they believed they had found the right person.

Creating a team of All-Stars in every position. Vitalii Dodonov Alyssa (Dyer) Williams Lauren Giovannetti

3. Inviting: Noah is awesome at making his audience feel a part of his journey. With events, giveaways, and being on his channel. Noah’s content feels more like a community than a class.

Because of these Noah has become more legitimate and likeable.

How do you win against a giant like Adobe?

(the answer seems counterintuitive)

You do it by niching down.

Here’s how Canva niched down to beat Adobe:

In 2013 SMBs were flocking to Facebook to market their businesses.

But the problem was that design tools at the time were complex.

These SMBs needed professional-looking designs
- cover photos
- social media posts
- flyers
- event banners

And they needed them quickly and easily.

In stepped Canva.

They positioned their product to solve this huge pain point of SMBs.

Once Canva started to wedge itself into these SMBs, it became easier to convert these individual users into team users of Canva.

As well as having the authority to expand to bigger enterprises.

Here’s how Morning Brew grew to 4 million subscribers serving hubs:

They have this awesome analogy of thinking about growth like a bicycle wheel.
Stay with me.

Every wheel has a hub and spokes attached to it.

The spokes are all the people who should read Morning Brew.

And the hubs are the people who have access to the spokes.

i.e., The individuals who can give you access to many people.

For Morning Brew, the first hubs they used were professors and club presidents.

They could give them access to speak in front of students.

But this couldn’t scale.

They couldn’t go around the whole country and pitch to every class at every university.

So now what?

But this couldn’t scale.

They couldn’t go around the whole country and pitch to every class at every university.

So now what?

They had exhausted all their classes and clubs.

So they turned their subscribers into champions.

Creating new hubs.

So they filtered their subscribers by domain names for schools they wanted a presence at.

And asked students if they wanted to be Morning Brew ambassadors.

They had opened the floodgates.

300 ambassadors at 200 schools.

All automated. And no rigorous screening process.

(although they made it seem like there was)

This appearance was crucial in getting buy-in and ownership from the ambassadors.

It made them feel special.

(don’t underestimate how powerful this feeling is)

They now had their new hubs.

The Alexs and Austins at universities around the country.

(don’t underestimate how powerful this feeling is)

They now had their new hubs.

The Alexs and Austins at universities around the country.

They use this same idea now with their open referral program.

Turning anyone into a Morning Brew Champion.

So find your first hubs.

Then evolve into more scalable ways to leverage them.

For Morning Brew, they started with hubs in their immediate circle.
(unscalable)

Then they used this same idea at universities around the country.
(somewhat scalable)

Then they turned this into a completely automated referral system.

I spent 20+ hours studying how ClickUp bootstrapped to profitability before a $4B valuation. Here’s what I learned:

1️⃣ Ship fast:

ClickUp chooses progress over perfection.

A core value at the company.

Believing that high-frequency compounds.

And getting to perfect at a faster rate.

So they focused on iterating user feedback balanced with their vision.

Delivering on features, requests, and bug fixes.

And delivering fast.

Most people wait for luck.

The best founders create it.

But how do you create luck?

Isn’t that against what luck is?

No, because there are two types of luck:

1. Passive luck:

What most people think of when they think of luck.

It’s your blind luck. And you have no control over it.

For example, what country you’re born in - you have ZERO control over this.

But it’s actually very hard to think of other examples you can’t influence.

Winning the lotto - just buy more tickets.

Finding money on the floor - walk in richer, more cash-heavy neighborhoods.

This leads me to the second type of luck.

2. Generated luck

Luck you can increase your chances of receiving.

And is how you should view luck.

As something you can influence.

2. Generated luck

Luck you can increase your chances of receiving.

And is how you should view luck.

As something you can influence.

Take the above examples. Most people would consider those events blind luck.

But they’re not.

Now I’m not saying there’s no chance involved.

But rather, you can increase your chances of luck.

Let’s use football (soccer) as an analogy.

Essentially every shot has an element of chance.

Some things you can’t control in the moment: the keeper, the wind, the ball’s pressure.

But take a shot again. And again. And again.

Now your odds of having scored are dramatically higher.

So although you can’t eliminate chance. You can increase your shots on goal.

And that’s how you should approach your business.

So although you can’t eliminate chance. You can increase your shots on goal.

And that’s how you should approach your business.

Constantly shooting small tests and seeing which is the game-winning shot.

There’s a great quote from a fellow South African, and one of the greatest golfers of all time, Gary Player.

“The more I practice. The luckier I get.”

How to make your landing page count:

1️⃣ It’s not about the text:

This might sound counterintuitive. But great writing is a result of clear thinking.

So you need to deeply understand your users:

- What is the pain point your users want to fix? (e.g. they are losing deals)

- Why are they experiencing this pain? (e.g. they are missing follow-up calls because their CRM is not user-friendly)

- What is the result your users desire? (e.g. to close more deals)

- How can people use your product to get results? (e.g. get customers on sales calls with more effective communication)

How do you answer these questions?

Speak to your users. And don’t just use forms.

Speak to your users. And don’t just use forms. You want to get on video calls with them or meet them in person.

2️⃣ The Slippery Slope:

The only goal of each section on your landing page is to get users to the next section - until the ask.

To do this, break every section down into a singular goal.

For example, the first section should be about hooking the user to read on - get to the point, but don’t quite close the loop yet - leave something unanswered that gets people to read on.

Only at the end do you close that curiosity gap, having walked them through the landing page. One goal at a time:

- Hooking potential customers
- Getting them curious.
- Showing authority.
- Relating to them.

One goal at a time:

- Hooking potential customers
- Getting them curious.
- Showing authority.
- Relating to them.
- Telling them how exactly you help.
- Making the ask.

3️⃣ Squash the objections:

Potential customers will always have concerns. Sometimes they’ll ask you. But most times they won’t.

That’s why answering objections in your copy is super important. You don’t want potential customers to leave because of any unanswered questions.

There are a few ways to do this.

The first is to address potential objections throughout your landing page.

For example, if you look at Guillaume Moubeche and lemlist’s customer reviews, you see a few objections squashed there already, e.g.

“lemlist is so simple to use, easy to connect with your CRM...”

Straight away, any doubts of a high-learning curve are gone. Plus I now know I can easily connect this to my CRM - lovely!

A customer feedback section is a great to organically address concerns in a natural and trustworthy way.

Another common way to address concerns is with an FAQ section.

Use what you hear in sales calls or customer meetings to address common concerns in a quick and concise manner.

If you get a super common objection, it might be worth creating a standalone section on your landing page to address it and show off your product’s ability to handle it.

When building your landing page always keep your customer in mind. Make sure you know what drives and motivates them and how this fits into your product - highlight that.

Selling a new product or service is hard. 
 
Don't make it harder by targeting everyone. 
 
Here are three reasons why you should niche down when starting your business: 
 
1️⃣ Stand out with a specific offer 
 
If you sell copywriting services for everyone, your offer can't be differentiated from your competition. 
 
You haven't given me any reason to choose you over other, more established companies. 
 
But suppose you sell copywriting services to CEOs of scale-ups that recently raised Series B funding. Now your offer can be extremely specific. 
 
And these CEOs will be more likely to pick you because they will feel like you understand them.  
 
2️⃣ "Competition is for losers" 
 
When you niche down, you can enter a market with a competition of one - yourself.

It reminds me of the famous Peter Thiel quote above. 
 
Find a niche where no one is serving them specifically - or there is a huge gap in demand and supply. 
 
This way you will become unique. 
 
3️⃣ Target everyone. Appeal to no one. 
 
When you target everyone your messaging has to be vague. 
 
And when business owners are spending money they want specifics on what will be delivered to them. 
 
So in the end, unless you have a recognizable brand name. You will appeal to no one.

Using your own product can explode growth

Here are 4 reasons to eat your own dog food:

1️⃣ Understand your customers better: Using your own product helps you relate to customers. Understanding their needs and the best ways your product can solve them.

2️⃣ Find new product ideas: Realize your product doesn’t quite solve all your needs? Your customers probably feel the same way as you. This is a perfect way to spot where a new feature or integration is needed.

3️⃣ Spot bugs and frustrations quickly: Using your product frequently, allows you to spot bugs and potential areas that are frustrating your users sooner.

4️⃣ Build trust with your customers: If you believe in your product enough to use it, your customers will feel like they can too.

Deel is a great example of this - using their product to manage their global remote team since day 1.

Going to market is hard. 
 
Don't make it harder by making this mistake 
 
Far too often founders try to target everyone right from the start. 
 
Instead what you should do is find a subset of customers, a wedge, that will open the door for you to expand later. 
 
By doing this, you can create more targeted messaging - helping your customer acquisition. As well as shape your product to solve your wedge customer's specific problems better than any other tool. 
 
Finding a wedge customer makes your life a lot easier as a founder - and it sets you up for sustainable growth down the line.

Wondering how to make launching easier? 
 
Find a crowd desperate to solve a problem. 
 
It’s much harder to make a profitable business by solving a “cherry-on-the-top” problem. 
 
You want to find a problem that people care deeply about. 
 
Even if this means targeting a smaller group of people - It’s worth sacrificing at the beginning. 
 
Because it will be much easier to market and sell to people who have a desperate need for a solution than people who would just sort of like a solution.

Want to build trust with potential customers? 🔒 
 
Provide real value. 
 
Want to convert more free users to paid users? 💵 
 
Provide more value.  
 
Want to keep users happy and not churning? 🤗 
 
Just keep providing value. 
 
Make it seem silly for them to stop using your product. 
 
Build a relationship with your users to the point where they don’t want to stop using your product. And not just because it serves their needs. 
 
But because they also like you and your brand. 
 
Why does giving value through content achieve this so well? 
 
Because not only does it build trust, loyalty, and authority. 
 
But it also leverages reciprocity.

Because not only does it build trust, loyalty, and authority. 
 
But it also leverages reciprocity. 
 
Your users will want to give something of value to you (a referral, a share, or a subscription) because you first gave something of value to them (articles, newsletter, tools, videos, free features) 
 
Reciprocity is powerful. Use it.

Useful is cool. But simple is better. 
 
Canva is a great example. 
 
Canva is the simplest solution on the market. Not the most powerful. But now has ~5x more users than Photoshop. 
 
Canva creates what I like to call a Simplicity Flywheel. Canva is simple to: 
- Find 🕵️ 
- Get started 🌟 
- Use 🧰 
- Share 📢 
 
𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗱 🕵️ 
 
Google something like “how to design a logo” and guess what pops up on the first page? 
 
Canva.

Canva. 
 
Try something like “how to choose brand colors”. 
 
Canva. 
 
Okay one more, Google “how to make a YouTube thumbnail”. 
 
Two videos of some guy telling me I can make free thumbnails that convert? Huh? 
 
Oh wait - guess what platform he uses? 
 
Canva. 
 
With the Canva thumbnail tutorial right underneath it by the way! 
 
𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁𝗲𝗱 🌟 
 
Canva has spent countless hours perfecting its onboarding process.

They identified that it wasn’t only the complexity of tools they needed to solve for, but also people’s confidence to design. 
 
This is why they have structured their onboarding to get you to complete a design in a few minutes. If you don’t do it straight away, they make sure to remind you via email. 
 
You get to see how quick and easy the platform is to use. And you make a cool design. 
 
An instant confidence boost. 
 
Canva also provides a ton of content on how to use their platform, how to achieve certain jobs (designs), and how to design better - making their users even more confident in getting started.

𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘂𝘀𝗲 🧰 
 
The core feature of Canva. 
 
Create beautiful designs, without all the fuss of a highly technical tool like Photoshop. 
 
It's simple to use - for everybody. 
 
Canva has become their vision of an all-in-one design platform, where anyone can bring their creative visions to life. 
 
No steep learning curves. 
 
No need for more tools.

No steep learning curves. 
 
No need for more tools. 
 
𝗦𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲 📢 
 
One of the most critical parts of the flywheel is how simple Canva is to share. 
 
Canva achieves this in a few ways: 
1. Inherently shared through use (marketing on Facebook, Instagram, etc). 
 
2. Integrates with a few social platforms, removing the friction to posting - allowing you to share and schedule designs from within Canva. 
 
3. Simple to add team members and collaborate with them. 
 
4. Users are proud of their designs, they want to share exactly how they made them.

4. Users are proud of their designs, they want to share exactly how they made them. 
 
The Canva Simplicity Flywheel then starts again...

One of the biggest enemies to building your startup is not understanding your customers. 
 
If you want to be ahead of your competition - research and speak to more potential customers than anyone else. 
 
Every successful founder can empathize with their customers. 
 
You don’t want to have to guess what your customers want or need. 
 
You want to understand them in such a way that you are certain what they need solved. 
 
Put yourself in their shoes and ask what problems you would like solved and how you would like to be marketed to. 
 
Building the best product possible requires rooting it in empathy for your customers.

A lot of founders make the same mistake when growing. 
 
They focus on doing and not hiring. 
 
To build a successful company, you need great people. 
 
How you are judged as a founder, in the end, is how well you hire. 
 
As Graham Weaver, founder of Alpine Investors put it: 
 
If you hire B grade people. You are a B grade leader. If you want to be an A+ leader, you need to hire A+ people.

I grew 100,000 followers on Instagram in 7 months. Here are my top three tips: 
 
1. Be consistent. I posted three times a day. Every day. For 7 months straight. On top of this, I posted at least 2 stories every day as well. 
 
2. Genuinely engage with others. Leave thoughtful comments on at least five posts daily. 
 
3. Test a lot. Algorithms change almost weekly, to stay on top of them you need to test a lot. Reels are the best now, but it used to be videos, and before that carousels and before that videos on story post, etc.

Building a great product is not about adding features you think your users will like. 
 
You need to deeply understand and empathize with your customers. 
 
This should drive your product development. 
 
Don’t guess what your customers want. Speak to them.

Building trust with your customers is hard.

Building in public makes it 100x easier.

Be extremely open and honest with your customers and they will instantly trust you.

Take John Hu from Stan for example:

John is extremely open with his audience. Both personally and with Stan. He doesn’t shy away from topics like his struggles with mental health and burnout - even to the point where he almost stepped down as CEO.

He brings you along his journey. Unfiltered.

Talking through Stan’s finances, pitch deck, investor meetings, and interviews. Essentially everything. Even sharing his investor updates.

When you embrace transparency with your users, it builds an engaged and loyal community who trust you, and importantly for your business, are more willing to buy from you.

Find what you’re comfortable sharing.

Find what you’re comfortable sharing. And find a community to share it with - whether it’s Reddit, a private Discord community, YouTube, Twitter/X, or even local events.

You never know who might be listening: a potential co-founder, investor, customer, or a founder friend.

It’s important to drive organic users and listen to their feedback, but to build users’ trust you have to iterate and ship fast. 
 
This is how ClickUp has become a leading example of Product-Led Growth. 
 
In 2022 alone, they added 100+ new features and integrations. 
 
This helped strengthen their users’ trust in them and turned them into their best advertisers. Because they felt heard. 
 
ClickUp is very clear to choose progress over perfection. A core value at the company. Because they believe that high frequency compounds over time - getting to perfect at a faster rate. 
 
So they launch a new release every Friday. Consistently. 
 
This speed and consistency has become a massive competitive advantage - their competition can’t keep up.

Consistently. 
 
This speed and consistency has become a massive competitive advantage - their competition can’t keep up. 
 
Because unlike their competition, they were okay with launching imperfect products. 
 
They knew they would improve them with the help of their users. 
 
This quick iteration boosted overall efficiency, which matters as much as growth in the early stages of your product. 
 
ClickUp used this bias toward action and learnt to tolerate the risk of failure in order to build a better product that their customers felt a part of.

The CEO of JPMorgan Chase wished that the Chase Sapphire Reserve Credit Card made negative $400M. Why?

Because there’s a tried and true FinTech playbook that people like Jamie Dimon and Eric Wei understand.

- Start with a simple, easy to understand “wedge” product, like a credit card. 💳

- Acquire enough customers to develop a unique underwriting model, with your customers' data. 📊

- Scale that model into other products, for example, home loans. 🏡

It’s a long-term game, but the idea is that all the acquisition expenses for the wedge product are made up for once those customers start using other products.

For Chase, they believed there was a high chance you’d switch over to a bank account and other Chase products after using the Sapphire Reserve Card.

Hence why they wished they made a bigger loss on their wedge credit card.

Finding Product-Market Fit (PMF) is hard. 
 
Your first product probably won’t stick. 
 
You need to stay agile and test to find PMF. 
 
Founders of Karat, now famous for their iconic black credit card for creators, started as business capital for creators. 
 
But this wasn’t intuitive to many creators - who are often young or unaware of finances. 
 
So Karat pivoted. 
 
To taxes for creators. 
 
But this didn’t work. 
- No one likes talking about taxes. 
- And when they do, they talk to someone they already trust. 
 
They knew they needed a product with two key features: 
 
- Intuitive to creators. 
- Easy to build trust. 
 
Enter the Karat Business Credit Card. 
 
PMF on their third try.

- Easy to build trust. 
 
Enter the Karat Business Credit Card. 
 
PMF on their third try. 
 
Make sure to pivot (if needed) to find your PMF.

Don't solve a problem a large group of people only sort of care about.

Solve a problem that a smaller group cares deeply about.

This will allow for your users to truly love your product.

Rather than kind of like it.

Karat Financial did exactly this.

Initially targeting Creators who have high working capital needs to speed up their production of content.

Do you know how companies like Stan and Karat Financial have managed to scale using organic marketing? 📈

One way is by leveraging Creators as inherent distribution channels to create a Tipping Point. 

Best-selling author Malcolm Gladwell identifies three crucial types of people needed for a product to reach a Tipping Point - i.e., spread like wildfire, or in the creator world, go viral.

- Connectors: Usually know and keep in touch with a lot of people. These are people with a special gift with linking us to the world.

- Mavens: Information specialists. They know what’s hot and what’s not. These are the people who amass loads of information and love to share it.

- Salesmen: Able to build instant rapport with people. Charismatic.

- Salesmen: Able to build instant rapport with people. Charismatic. These are the people who are socially contagious.

The awesome thing about creators is that they are all three combined. Both Stan and Karat use this as a superpower to grow their businesses.

- Connecting them with other creators and their audiences (where other creators, potential customers, also often hang out).

- Using their social authority to influence other creators to use their products. If leading creators are using them. I should too.

- Aligning creators incentives with theirs with referral programs (Stan) and bringing them on as investors (Karat). Their customers now become their salespeople, using their social presence and charisma to grow their customer bases.

So when building, think about how you can serve Creators!

All top content creators use this method to save time and increase reach 🚀

Gary Vaynerchuk (aka Gary Vee) bases his whole content strategy on this.

It's called the "content pyramid method"

It start with your core piece of content. Generally a longer piece of content like a YouTube video, podcast, or newsletter.

This core piece of content can then be cut up and repurposed into short-form content like TikToks, Reels, and Twitter/X threads.

But the key is to not stop there.

You can then use that core content to continuously post content snippets. Short posts on LinkedIn, Twitter/X, Reddit, Quora, or even Instagram stories.

These snippets can be used to drive awareness and engagement back to the core content, closing the cycle.

These snippets can be used to drive awareness and engagement back to the core content, closing the cycle.

Don't guess what your customers want. Speak to them.
Here's why:

Recently, I did a deep dive into Stan's journey from $0 to $15M in just three years. One of the insights that has stuck with me is Stan's unwavering commitment to putting the customer first.

The team at Stan understands that building a great product is not about adding features you think will be cool.

It’s about deeply understanding and empathizing with your customer, and using this to shape your product.

Stan have been so intentional about putting the customer first, that now over 45% of their customers say they would be extremely disappointed if they couldn't use Stan again (anything above 40% is a good sign of Product-Market Fit).

The awesome thing about building with the customer first, i.e., creating a great product that your customers actually want, is that it generally leads to success for customers, which leads to customers referring your business, which leads to new customers.

Which leads to them having success, which leads to them referring your businesses… it becomes a never-ending cycle, or as the Stan team calls it, a Growth Flywheel.

This strategy has been so successful for Stan, that now the average Stan customer refers 2+ new users over their lifetime.
